section.title: Introduction to Vector Spaces (Real Coordinate Spaces)

subsection.title: Introduction to Vector Spaces
subsection.p: A vector space is a space of vectors. Broadly, a space is a set of objects which satisfy some specific conditions. In particular, vector spaces are sets of vectors for which we can perform the fundamental operations for vectors: addition and scalar multiplication. That is, we can take linear combinations.

Slightly more precisely, a vector space is a set V of vectors for which adding any two vectors in V is a vector that is also in V, and the scalar multiple of any vector in V is also in V. In other words, adding and scaling vectors in the space stays in the space.

definition.p: A vector space is a set of vectors V such that,

ol.li: If \vec{v} \in V and c \in \mathbb{R}, then c\vec{v} \in V also.

subsection.p: This property that combining objects through some operation producing another object also within the set is called closure. Then, a vector space is a set of vectors which is closed under addition and scalar multiplication. More compactly, we can say a vector space is closed under taking linear combinations.

example.title: The vector space \mathbb{R}^2
example.p: The set \mathbb{R}^2 of all vectors with two real number components, is a vector space.

example.title: The vector space \mathbb{R}
example.p: The real numbers \mathbb{R} can also be considered a vector space.

example.title: The vector space \mathbb{R}^n
example.p: More generally, \mathbb{R}^n is a vector space.

Then, in \mathbb{R}^2, this forms a line, in particular a line through the origin (0,0), and through \vec{v}.

subsection.title: Span of n Vectors
subsection.definition:
Let \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_p \in \mathbb{R}^n be vectors. The span of \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_p, denoted by \Span{\vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_n}, is the set of all linear combinations of \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_p. In other words,
\Span{\vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_p} = \set{a_1 \vec{v}_1 + \dots a_n \vec{v}_p : a_1, \dots, a_p \in \mathbb{R}}
subsection.p: By definition, a vector \vec{v} is in \Span{\vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_p} if and only if \vec{v} can be written as a linear combination of \vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_p. subsection.title: Subspaces
subsection.p: Many interesting vector spaces are subsets of other vectors spaces. This naturally leads to the concept of a vector subspace.

defintion.p: Let V be a vector space. Then, a subset U \subseteq V is a vector subspace of V (or simply subspace) if U is itself a vector space.

subsection.p: For now, most of the vector spaces we encounter will be subspaces of \mathbb{R}^n, for some n.

example.title: Subspaces of \mathbb{R}^2
example.p: Consider the possible subspaces of \mathbb{R}^2. Let U \subseteq \mathbb{R}^2 be a subspace. First, notice that if \vec{v} \in U is any vector, then 0 \vec{v} = \vec{0} is also in U, because U is closed under scalar multiplication. Thus, any subspace of \mathbb{R}^2 must contain the zero vector. Indeed, the vector space containing only the zero vector U = \set{\vec{0}} is a vector space. This can be trivially verified, since any scalar multiple of \vec{0} is \vec{0}, and any sum of \vec{0} is \vec{0}.

Then, suppose U contains any non-zero vector \vec{d} \neq \vec{0}. Then, U must also contain all scalar multiples of \vec{d}. Thus, U must contain the line parallel to \vec{d} and through the origin. Indeed, this set, which is a line in \mathbb{R}^2, or the span of \vec{d}, is a vector space.

Indeed, if \vec{u}, \vec{v} \in U, then they are both scalar multiples of \vec{d}. Then, \vec{u} = a \vec{d}, \vec{v} = b \vec{d} for some scalars a, b \in \mathbb{R}. Then, \vec{u} + \vec{v} = a\vec{d} + b\vec{d} = (a + b) \vec{d} is also a scalar multiple of \vec{d}, and so is also in U. Also, for any scalar c, c\vec{v} = (cb) \vec{v} is also a scalar multiple of \vec{d}, and so is in U. Thus, U is a vector space.

Next, suppose that U contains another vector which is not parallel to \vec{d}, say these two vectors are now called \vec{v}_1 and \vec{v}_2. Then, their span is a vector space. In this case, it makes up the entire plane \mathbb{R}^2.
In summary, the possible subspaces of \mathbb{R}^2 are a single point (the origin), a line through the origin, and the entire plane.

example.title: Subspaces of \mathbb{R}^3
example.p: The possible subspaces of \mathbb{R}^3 are a single point (the origin), a line through the origin, a plane through the origin, or the entire 3D space.

The Column Space
subsection.p: Subspaces often arise in connection with some matrix A. The two most important ways to construct subspaces are called the column space and null space, of a matrix.

definition.p: The column space of a matrix A is the set of all linear combinations of the column vectors of A. More precisely, if A is an m \times n matrix, A = \begin{bmatrix} \vec{a}_1 \amp \dots \amp \vec{a}_n \end{bmatrix}, then the column space, denoted by C(A), is defined by,

subsection.p: The column space of an m \times n matrix A is a subspace of \mathbb{R}^m (since the column vectors are vectors in \mathbb{R}^m).

Recall that \vec{b} is in the span of \vec{a}_1, \dots, \vec{a}_n if and only if the linear system A\vec{x} = \vec{b} has a solution. Then, the column space is equiavlently the set of all vectors \vec{b} such that A\vec{x} = \vec{b} has a solution. Conversely, A\vec{x} = \vec{b} has a solution precisely when \vec{b} is in the column space of A.

subsection.title: The Null Space

definition.p: Let A be an n \times m matrix. Then, the null space of A, N(A), is the set of all solutions to the homogeneous system A\vec{x} = \vec{0}. In other words, it is the set of all vectors \vec{x} such that A\vec{x} = \vec{0}, or

subsection.p: Certainly, the zero vector \vec{0} \in N(A), because A\vec{0} = \vec{0} for any matrix A.

theorem.p: The null space is a subspace. More precisely, if A is an n \times m matrix, then N(A) is a subspace of \mathbb{R}^n.

proof.p: Let \vec{x}, \vec{y} \in N(A), c \in \mathbb{R}. Then, A\vec{x} = \vec{0} and A\vec{y} = \vec{0}. Then,
and so c\vec{x} \in N(A). Thus, N(A) is a subspace.

subsection.p: The null space is unique in that for a general matrix A and vector \vec{b}, the set of all solutions \vec{x} such that A\vec{x} = \vec{b} is not a vector space (i.e. if \vec{b} \neq \vec{0}). For example, because \vec{0} is not a solution and so is not in the solution set. Graphically, the solution set may be a line or plane which does not go through the origin.

The null space is defined by specifying a condition for which its vectors must satisfy. On the other hand, the column space is defined by specifying how to construct each vector by linear combinations. For this reason, the null space is said to be defined implicitly, whereas the column space is defined explicitly. To determine an explicit description of N(A), solve the homogeneous system A\vec{x} = \vec{0}, and write the solution set in parametric vector form.
